titleHead: Help with your appeal - Appeal a benefit decision - GOV.UK
title: Appeal a benefit decision
heading: 3. Help with your appeal
support: There’s various support available before and during your appeal.

representative.unableToManage: If you think you’ll be unable to manage your appeal on your own you may want the help of a representative. They often work for a charity or welfare rights organisation and will provide their services for free.
representative.goodRep: A good representative can help you do one or more of the following:

helpList.process: advise you on the appeals process
helpList.evidence: help you prepare evidence to support your appeal
helpList.statement: help you prepare a written statement
helpList.actOnBehalf: act on your behalf during your appeal
helpList.hearing: help you explain your appeal at the hearing
helpList.afterDecision: advise you on what to do after the tribunal have made a decision

representative.anyone: Anyone can be your representative, including friends and family.
representative.sentInfo: Anyone who is registered as a representative will be sent all the information relating to your appeal, including medical evidence. They can also act on your behalf during the appeal but they should only do this with your permission.

telephoneSupport.contactCentre: Telephone support is available if you need help using the service. If you need legal advice then contact a representative (see section above).

financialSupport.contact: Your appeal can take several months. If you think you’ll struggle for money you should contact DWP, Jobcentre Plus or your local council to see whether they can help. You can find DWP's contact details on any correspondence from them.
